channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israeli Airstrike in Gaza Strip Kills Palestinian
item.description: The airstrike that killed a Palestinian, who was believed to be a militant, and injured two others came hours after a rocket fired from Gaza hit southern Israel.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and FARES AKRAM

item.title: Help for Referees, in a Can
item.description: A referee can spray what looks like shaving cream at the spot where a free kick should be taken before pacing off the 10 yards where a wall will form.
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: A referee using a foam spray to mark where a kick should take place during a training session in Rio de Janeiro. The spray is used in M.L.S. games.

item.title: Tehran Journal: Iran’s World Cup Zeal Wanes as Match Draws Near
item.description: Iran has shown little of the excitement in the days prior to the tournament that it displayed during last year’s qualifying games.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Iran’s Team Melli at a poorly attended farewell ceremony in Tehran this month, ahead of the 2014 World Cup in Brazil.

item.title: Technocrat to Populist, an Afghan Transformed
item.description: The transformation of Ashraf Ghani into something akin to an Afghan populist is perhaps the most surprising story line in the Afghan presidential campaign.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ashraf Ghani, a former finance minister who is a candidate in the runoff vote for Afghanistan’s president, before a campaign event in Kabul on Wednesday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Mosul Falls to ISIS, Endangering Iraq’s Democracy
item.description: Shiite rulers must reach out to Sunnis or lose the country.
item.dc:creator: By NUSSAIBAH YOUNIS

item.title: Iraq Said to Seek U.S. Strikes on Militants
item.description: The Obama administration declined the request by Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, because it was reluctant to open a new chapter in a conflict that the White House has insisted was closed.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Iraqi families fleeing violence in the northern province of Nineveh arrived Wednesday at a checkpoint in Aski Kalak in Iraqi Kurdistan, an autonomous region.

item.title: Iraq Militants, Pushing South, Aim at Capital
item.description: After seizing control of Mosul, Sunni militants occupied the key oil refining town of Baiji and seized the city of Tikrit, security officials and residents said.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By SUADAD AL-SALHY and TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Burned vehicles belonging to Iraqi security forces on Wednesday, the day after Sunni insurgents seized control of the city of Mosul.

item.title: Before Army, P.O.W. Failed At Coast Guard Training
item.description: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl spent just short of a month in basic training with the United States Coast Guard in early 2006 before he was given an administrative discharge, military officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Open Source: Egyptian Dissident Sentenced For Challenging Ban on Protest
item.description: One of Egypt’s most prominent dissidents, the blogger Alaa Abdel Fattah, was arrested on Wednesday outside the Cairo court where he was convicted in absentia.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Alaa Abd El Fattah, an Egyptian activist, was forced to wait outside a courtroom at Cairo's Torah Prison on Wednesday while he was tried in absentia inside.

item.title: Top Militant Leader Is Arrested in Philippines
item.description: Khair Mundos, 50, a leader of Abu Sayyaf, was arrested on Wednesday morning in southern Manila, according to a statement from the police.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: Tax Breaks for Apple and Starbucks Investigated by E.U.
item.description: The European Union has begun an investigation into how low-tax nations like Ireland have helped large multinationals like Apple and Starbucks reduce their tax bills by billions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER and LANDON THOMAS Jr.
item.media:description: The office of Apple Operations International, a subsidiary of Apple, in Hollyhill, Cork, Ireland.

item.title: Bits Blog: Traffic Snarls in Europe as Taxi Drivers Protest Against Uber
item.description: The start-up that digitally links passengers and freelance drivers has expanded beyond the United States to cities including London, Paris and Berlin — all of them the sites of Wednesday’s protests.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT

item.title: Missile Strike by C.I.A. Drone Kills at Least 4, Pakistan Reports
item.description: Victims of the attack were said to include members of a Taliban-allied faction that held Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl in captivity.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Morocco’s King Slow to Deliver on Pro-Democracy Vows
item.description: Three years after King Mohammed VI responded to pro-democracy protests by pledging changes, rights activists and others say the government still uses force to quell dissent.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By AIDA ALAMI
item.media:description: King Mohammed VI of Morocco, center, and President Moncef Marzouki of Tunisia, right, reviewing troops in Tunis in May.

item.title: The Weight of the World Rests on Brazil
item.description: Brazil, the country that has become synonymous with soccer, has no choice but to win the tournament. But Argentina looms.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREAS CAMPOMAR
item.media:description: Brazilians expect Coach Luiz Felipe Scolari’s team to win the nation’s sixth World Cup title. The final is set for July 13.

item.title: Militants Storm Turkish Consulate in Iraqi City, Taking 49 People as Hostages
item.description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey held an emergency meeting with top security officials amid a diplomatic effort to free the hostages in Mosul.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Sunni Fighters Gain as They Battle 2 Governments, and Other Rebels
item.description: Fighters of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, a magnet for militants from around the world, have a religious conviction and canny business sense.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By THANASSIS CAMBANIS
item.media:credit: ISIS, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An image taken from a video uploaded on Sunday by the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria claiming to show fighters in Tikrit, Iraq.

item.title: Ukraine and Russia Still Far Apart on Gas Deal
item.description: As the second day of talks broke down, President Vladimir V. Putin urged officials in Kiev to accept Moscow’s latest price offer for natural gas imports.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: F.B.I. Begins Criminal Inquiry in V.A. Scandal
item.description: The F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, said the bureau was looking into accusations that Department of Veterans Affairs officials had manipulated medical waiting lists.
item.dc:creator: By MATT APUZZO

item.title: Campaign to Crack Down on Fringe Sects in China Worries Mainstream Churches
item.description: The campaign was prompted by the murder of a woman at a McDonald’s that horrified the nation and was attributed to adherents of a religious group.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: China Central Television, via Associated Press
item.media:description: This image taken from Chinese television shows Zhang Lidong, a suspect in the murder of a woman at a McDonald’s in Shandong Province last month.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: June 11
item.description: Parupalli Kashyap, an Indian badminton player, hitting a return shot while playing against Riichi Takeshita of Japan during a first round match in Tokyo, Japan.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: India's Parupalli Kashyap in action against Japan's Riichi Takeshita during a men's singles first round match at the Japan Open badminton tournament in Tokyo.

item.title: Egyptian Leader Apologizes to Victim of Sexual Assault in Tahrir Square
item.description: In a televised visit to the hospital bed of a woman assaulted in Tahrir Square, President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi declared his commitment to combat sexual violence against women in Egypt.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Hagel Defends Bergdahl Trade as a Part of Waging War
item.description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel was the first high-level official to publicly face lawmakers about a prisoner swap that has angered many in both parties.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI and CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel testified before the House Armed Services Committee on Wednesday.

item.title: Letter From India: Fixing India’s Deadly Roads
item.description: Not even politicians are safe while driving on Indian roads. To project a modern, respectable image, the country should fix that.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi, left, placed a wreath on the coffin of India's minister of rural development, Gopinath Munde, who died in a car accident.

item.title: Icon of Egypt's 2011 Revolt Sentenced to 15 Years
item.description: An Egyptian court on Wednesday convicted a prominent activist from the country's 2011 uprising of organizing an unauthorized protest and assaulting a policeman, sentencing him to 15 years in prison, in the latest blow to the liberal pro-democracy movement at a time of rapidly eroding freedoms.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
